But what happens if a lamp breaks or a component is
disconnected?
In a series circuit, if a lamp breaks or a component is disconnected, the circuit is broken, and all the components stop working at the same time.
So, Series circuits are useful if you want a warning that one of the components in the circuit has failed. They also use less wiring than parallel circuits.
Parallel circuits The components are connected in multiple branches, forming separate paths for the electric current to ﬂow In parallel circuits different components are connected on different branches of the wire. Meaning that the electric current has more than one path to ﬂow in the same circuit.

What happens if a lamp breaks or a component is
disconnected?
In a parallel circuit, if a lamp breaks or a component is disconnected from one parallel wire, the components on different branches keep working. So, Parallel circuits are useful if you want components to continue to work, even if one component has failed. This is why our homes are wired up with parallel circuits.

OHM’S LAW
Level 02 - Electricity - Lesson 04

Have you ever thought about how to calculate the
current owing in the circuit?
Ohm’s law is one of the most popular and important laws that helps us deﬁne the relationship between the most basic elements of power which are voltage, current, and resistance.
Resistance
Resistance (R) is a measure of the opposition to current ﬂow in an electrical circuit. Measured in ohms.
Current
Current is the ﬂow of electric charge carriers such as electrons. Electrical current ﬂows from negative to positive points. Measured in ampere (A).
Voltage
Voltage is the pressure from an electric circuit’s power source that pushes energized electrons (current) through a running loop, allowing them to perform work like illuminating a light. It is measured in Volt.
Level 02 - Electricity - Lesson 04

What is Ohm’s law?
Ohm’s law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points. Ohm’s law formula is written as;
V I Therefore, V = RI where R is a constant called resistance.
R depends on the dimensions of the conductor, and on the material of the conductor. Its unit is Ohm (Ω).
Ohm’s Law formula
Ohm’s law can be demonstrated in a mathematical form:
V = IR

AVOmeter – Multimeter
AVO meter stands for A – ampere, V – volt, O – ohm meter. It is also known as a multimeter. Avometer or multimeter is a tester that is used to measure electric current, the potential difference between two points in a circuit, and also measures resistance in a circuit.
It consists of a display screen, a dial, or buttons to select the type of measurement, and two probes (red and black) that are used to make contact with the electrical component being measured.
Measuring Voltage
To measure voltage, connect the avometer’s probes to the appropriate points in the circuit. Select the voltage range suitable for the expected measurement and read the displayed value on the avometer’s scale or digital screen.
Measuring Current
When measuring current, the avometer is placed in series with the circuit.
Level 02 - Electricity - Lesson 04

Measuring Resistance
To measure resistance, disconnect the component from the circuit or power source. Connect the avometer’s probes to the component’s terminals and set the avometer to the resistance measurement mode. Read the displayed resistance value on the scale or digital screen.
Here are the steps to use an Avo meter:
1. Select the type of measurement: The dial or buttons on the Avo meter allow you to select the type of measurement you want to make, such as voltage, current, or resistance.
2. Connect the probes: Depending on the type of measurement you are making, you will need to connect the probes to different parts of the circuit. For example, to measure voltage, you would connect the red probe to the positive side of the component being measured and the black probe to the negative side.
Note: the black probe is always connected to the com hole of the Avometer.
3. Take the measurement: Once the probes are connected, you can take the measurement by reading the value on the display screen. Make sure you are reading the correct units and range.
Level 02 - Electricity - Lesson 04

Some tips to keep in mind while using an Avo meter:
• Always make sure the probes are connected correctly before taking a measurement. • Be careful not to touch the probes while taking a measurement, as this can cause inaccurate readings or even damage the Avo meter. • Use the correct range and units for the measurement you are taking to ensure accurate results. • Always turn off the Avometer after use to conserve the battery.

LESSON 1 Mechatronics
GEARS
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 01

Have you ever wondered how do cars move?
When you push the fuel pedal the car moves, when the pedal is pushed harder it moves at a higher speed.
Thanks to the gearbox inside the car.
What are the gears? Gears are mechanisms that mesh together via teeth and are used to transmit rotary motion from one shaft to another. Geared devices can change the speed, torque, and direction of a power source.
Gears are deﬁned by two important items: radius and number of teeth. They are typically mounted, or connected to other parts, via a shaft or base.
When a large gear is connected with a small one, the smaller gear will rotate faster than the bigger one. Turning the big gear slowly will require less energy than it would rotate the small one quickly; so, by using gear, there is saving of energy and making work easier.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 01

Three basics, we should know to understand how gears transmit speed and torque.
Rotational velocity is the velocity of an object rotating around an axis.
Torque is a rotating force produced by a motor. The more torque the motor produces, the greater is its ability to perform work
Power
is how rapidly work is accomplished.
Power equals rotational velocity multiplied by the torque
So, the power-driven to any of the gears is either translated to torque or rotational velocity.
when two gears mesh together, power is applied to one of them and thus transmitted to the other.
the bigger gear will translate this power to large torque at the expense of the speed (high torque low speed), while the smaller gear will translate such power to high speed and low torque.
That's why cars need gearboxes. To begin with, a car needs a huge amount of force and very little speed to get it moving, so the driver uses the biggest gear.
Once the car's going, the driver switches to a smaller gear. More of the engine's power switches to making speed and the car goes faster.
The driver uses the gearshift to make the engine generate more force or more speed depending on whether hill-climbing power, acceleration from a standstill, or pure speed is needed.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 01

Why do we must press on a clutch before changing gears?
In practice, changing gears means meshing different sized gear wheels together, but you can't do that while the gearbox is transmitting power from the engine at high speed.
That's why you need to press a car's clutch pedal before changing gears, which disengages the engine's input from the gearbox.
The gear-box inside the car has dierent types of gears
Spur gears
spur gears are a type of cylindrical gear, with shafts that are parallel, and teeth that are straight and oriented parallel to the shafts. They’re the simplest and most common type of gear – easy to manufacture and suitable for a wide range of applications. The spur gears are typically used for lower-speed applications, although they can be used at almost any speed.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 01

Helical gears
Helical gears are one type of cylindrical gear where the teeth are curved compared to spur gears (straight teeth), properly designed helical gears can have a larger total contact ratio which can improve vibration and noise.
Worm gear
A worm gear is a gear consisting of a shaft with a spiral thread that engages with and drives a toothed wheel.
It changes the rotational movement by 90 degrees.
Bevel gear
Bevel gears are gears where the axes of the two shafts intersect.
Bevel gears are most often mounted on shafts that are 90 degrees apart but can be designed to work at other angles as well.
Rack and pinion gears
A rack and pinion are a type of linear actuator that comprises a circular gear engaging a linear gear, which operates to translate rotational motion into linear motion.
Driving the pinion into rotation causes the rack to be driven linearly. Driving the rack linearly will cause the pinion to be driven into a rotation.

PULLEY & BELTS
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

What Is Pulley?
Pulleys are simply a collection of one or more wheels over which you loop a rope to make it easier to lift things. Pulley is used singles or in combination to transmit energy & motion. For example, instead of pushing a load up, you can attach it to a rope and pulley above you and pulldown to move it up.
Mechanical advantage of pulley
Using multiple pulleys decreases the amount of force necessary to move an object by increasing the amount of rope used to raise the object. The mechanical advantage (MA) of a pulley system is equal to the number of ropes supporting the movable load.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

Types of pulleys
Fixed pulley
It is stationary, meaning that it cannot be moved. A ﬁxed pulley is used to redirect the force in a rope A ﬁxed pulley has a mechanical advantage of 1.
Movable pulley
It has an axle that is "free" to move in space. A movable pulley is used to transform forces. A movable pulley has a mechanical advantage of 2. That is, if one end of the rope is anchored, pulling on the other end of the rope will apply a doubled force to the object attached to the pulley.
Compound pulley
it is a combination ﬁxed and movable pulley system.
Remember gears are also used to transmit power
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

What is the dierence between gears and pulleys?
A gear is a toothed machine part, such as a wheel, that meshes with another toothed part to transmit motion or to change speed or direction.
However, they are not suitable when shafts are distant, they require lubrication due to the friction that occurs during contact between the teeth. Gears have no ﬂexibility. A pulley is a wheel with a grooved rim in which a rope can run in order to change the direction or point of application of a force applied to the rope
They are suitable for transmitting power between 2 different shafts when pulleys are attached to chains or belts. The pulley system is much ﬂexible than the gear system.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

Pulley and belt
The belt drive can also be used to change the speed of rotation, either up or down, by using different sized pulleys.
Belt drives transfer movement from one rotating pulley to another, each held on a shaft. Shafts and pulley wheels can be made out of any material, whereas pulley belts are generally made from a soft, ﬂexible material such as rubber.
In a pulley system, the belt can either drive the pulleys normally in one direction or the belt may be cross belt , so that the direction of the driven shaft is reversed.
Level 02 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

Idler pulley
The idler pulley is a common part that's found on the majority of the vehicles on the road. Its primary function is to provide tension and guide the engine drive belt.
Real-life applications on pulleys
• Elevator Elevators work via a powerful electronic pulley system. Elevators make use of a system of several pulleys and counterweights to provide the lift system with both power and safety.

What's on the board?
There are many varieties of Arduino boards that can be used for different purposes. Some boards look a bit different from the one below, but most Arduino boards have the majority of these components in common:
Power (USB / Barrel Jack)
Every Arduino board needs a way to be connected to a power source. The Arduino UNO can be powered from a USB cable coming from your computer or a power supply that is terminated in a barrel jack.
The USB connection is also how you will load code onto your Arduino board.
NOTE Do NOT use a power supply greater than 20 Volts as you will overpower (and thereby destroy) you’re Arduino. The recommended voltage for most Arduino models is between 6 and 12 Volts.
Level 02 - Arduino - Lesson 01

Pins (Digital, Analog, 5V& 3.3V, GND)
The pins on your Arduino are the places where you connect wires to construct a circuit.
Digital:
• Across from the analog pins are the digital pins (0 through 13 on the UNO). These pins can be used for both digital input (like telling if a button is pushed) and digital output (like powering an LED).
Analog
• The area of pins under the ‘Analog In’ label (A0 through A5 on the UNO) is Analog In pins. These pins can read the signal from an analog sensor (like a temperature sensor) and convert it into a digital value that we can read.
5V & 3.3V • As you might guess, the 5V pin supplies 5 volts of power, and the 3.3V pin supplies 3.3 volts of power. Most of the simple components used with the Arduino run off of 5 or 3.3 volts.
GND • Short for ‘Ground’. There are several GND pins on the Arduino, any of which can be used to ground your circuit.
Reset Button
The Arduino has a reset button. Pushing it will temporarily connect the reset pin to ground and restart any code that is loaded on the Arduino.
